content.description: (Chief Walker) This is a fun little warm-up and a good way to start a day out at Ruth Lake.  It begins on the far left of the Chief wall and climbs a less than vertical wall with a distinct finger crack starting about halfway up.  This is a good climb, however it is very short.
content.protection: Gear up to 1", and one bolt at the start plus anchors.  I also found a great slot for a #2 camalot placement about halfway up the finger crack

content.description: Pumpy, crux start! A must do!
content.location: Whitish rock face around the the corner from Yah-Keerah. The left route of the two.

content.description: Pumpfest from the start! Just do it!
content.location: Whitish rock face around the the corner from Yah-Keerah. The right route of the two. Eight feet right of White Fish.

content.description: (Sitting Bull) Start under a small roof on the next bolt line over from Yah-Keerah.  Climb through it and pull onto the nice face above.  The sequence just under the roof and pulling through the roof itself seemed to be the crux.  Once again, fun climbing that I wish lasted longer.

climbs.name: Too Many Chiefs
climbs.fa: R. Bert, P. Lenz on gear 8/29/13

content.description: This pitch is a traditionally protected crack/small chimney. The climbing is of fair quality, and the rock is generally solid. It protects well with traditional gear, but you can also reach left and clip bolts on an adjacent sport-climb pitch. It would thus be a very reasonable pitch for a beginning trad leader.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to 3 inches. You can reach leftward and clip bolts to an adjacent route if you must, but try placing your own gear instead. There are chain anchors at the top, which were placed to serve other climbs, but are perfectly situated for this one.

content.description: Angles up right for some vertical face climbing. Classic Ruth Lake Climbing!
content.location: Around the the corner from White Fish and White Buffalo

content.description: Climbed Quanah on 8/6/2019.  The route has been fully bolted.   Six bolts to top anchors.  Fun Route!
content.location: Most eastern route on Chief Wall.  10 feet left of Chief Po-bisho-e-quasho (Iron Jacket).

content.description:
Translated as Red Cloud, this is a hard, continuous, and sustained line up pockets and shallow edges. Difficult to read, the short and sweet

Red Cloud

will keep your mind and body busy. Thin and tricky to start,

Makhpiya-Luta

climbs up and slightly left over mis-leading holds and thin edges to a small, troublesome bulge. Pass this and exit on more comfortable ground. Climb to the left and follow the bolt line for the full value, climbing right of the bolts makes this line significantly easier.
content.protection: Draws for three or four bolts and an anchor.
content.location:
Makhpiya-Luta

is the first route you encounter when approaching the

Chief Wall

. Its the far most right climb and the only route with so few bolts.

content.description: Start in crack (Too Many Chiefs), then cross over left onto face as sport route. Great rock, fun route!
content.location: Same start as Too Many Chiefs. Just a few feet left of Kansas City Chiefs. Goes out of obvious large trad crack of Too Many Chiefs and up the face.

content.description: Straight up through the Big Horn! Vertical fun on solid flakes!
content.location: 10 feet right of General George Custer. Look up for the obvious "Big Horn"!

content.description:
This is the bolt line right of Too Many Chiefs. A bolted route on good quality rock.

If someone knows the first ascentionists and the name of this route, let me know,and I will add this info.
content.location: This bolt line is immediately right of Too Many Chiefs crack.

content.description:
Translated this is Chief Joseph. This route starts in a black streak climbing through a small bulge using side pulls and horizontal edges. The initial crux comes low before the hard to clip second bolt and the final crux is making the last moves before the anchor.

Big reaches, moves, and edges on steep stone! Get after it!
content.protection: Draws for five bolts and a chain anchor.
content.location:
This is the third route right of

Yah-Keerah

and is directly right of

Tatanka-Iyotanka

. It starts just right of the small vertical break.

content.description: Straight up vertical climb. Most of the moss is gone now! Geronimo!
content.location: Starts in alcove to the right of Yah-Keerah.

content.description:
Not the best route in the world, but certainly not the worst either.

Better than its been described,

General George Custer

is an odd line to say the least. Lacking the continuity of its neighbors, this climb's awkward and unsteady feel will begin to grow on you after the third bolt. Teeter your way slowly up the route using pinches, edges, crimps, and chips.  Maintaining balance and opposition will be a must on this fragile journey. Originally rated 5.10, opinions may vary.
content.protection: Draws for four bolts and an anchor.
content.location:
This is the fourth route from the right you when arriving at the

Chief Wall

and just left of Little Big Horn

content.description: Straight up the black streak above the roof. Very fun, positive route! Totally sick! (It's The Zims idea!) Go up left of black streak for 5.9 variation.
content.location: Around the corner (to the right) of Little Big Horn, 10 feet left of Makhpiya-Luta. Obvious roof above.

content.description: Sweet route! Look for finger pocket when swinging right to pull the roof!
content.location: On Corner, 6 feet left of Tatanka-Iyotanka

content.description: Fun route up wide crack. Stay right on route and pull through crux, small roof near top.
content.location: Eastern section of Chief Wall, 10 feet left of Scout.

content.description: Crux start! If leading have a spotter. Stand on the little rock, foot on the wall, as you leap for the hand ledge leading to the crack left. Left heel hook and voila! Fun start, then straight up the arete. Should get "your" hands shaking!
